notes.head: Incipit
notes.body: (1r/1) Brittene iȝland is ehta hund mila lang

notes.head: Note
notes.body: Fol. 91v is very badly worn and the final lines of the chronicle are virtually illegible.

objectDesc.extent:
210 mm x 145 mm (dimensions of most - size of leaves).
240 mm x 165 mm (dimensions of fols 86-90 - size of leaves).
objectDesc.layoutDescription: Written in 30 long lines. Fol. 91 is written on 29 lines, and fols 2-7 are written in two columns. Ruled in hard point, Quire 1, fols 1-10, and lead.

handDesc.summary: The manuscript is copied by two scribes over time.

hands.name: main text
hands.description: fols 1r-88v/9. The scribe wrote the text in different stages. Fols 1r-81r/10 was written at the same time. After that the writing changes in aspect and colour of ink, inidicating that the annals up to fol. 88v/9 were probably written in six blocks: 1122, 1123, 1124, 1125-6 'lande', 1126 'On þes'- 1127, 1128-31. The hand is a round English vernacular hand which uses both Caroline and insular letter-forms (see, also

characters.note: a: insular for English and Latin.
d: insular with ascender slightly curving to the right
f: insular.
g: insular.
r: insular.
s: insular. The low and high form of s are used indifferently.
ð: the same size as d, with a median stroke starting usually on the ascender and concluding with a dot to the left.
Short and tapered descenders curving to the left.
Infrequent (see, for a full analysis Irvine 2004, pp. xxiv-xxviii)
The head of nota ˥ is curved.

hands.name: main text
hands.description: Fols 88v/10-91. Scribe 2 writes in a clear upright and compressed minuscule, using mainly Caroline letter forms (

characters.note: f: with a descender often below the line.
r: with a descender often below the line.
s: with a descender often below the line.
þ used along with th.
ð used along with th.
u often used instead of ƿ.
ƿ used with u or uu.
Ƿ capital W always stands instead of Ƿ.
descenders often descend below the line, as they would not normally do in a Latin literary text of this date, and turn to the left at the end.
More frequent than Scribe 1 (see, for a full analysis Irvine 2004, pp. xxiv-xxviii)

history.origin: Copied at Peterborough Abbey in the twelfth-century. On fol. 1r there is an erased inscription, s. xiv: 'alienauerit...sit...et a celesti consolacione alienatus' (Ker 1957, p. 426).
history.provenance: William Cecil, Lord Burghleigh (1520-1598) owned the manuscript from which Laurence Nowell (d. 1576) made a transcription, now London, British Library, Add. 43704 in 1565 while he was in residence at Burghleigh House. Whitelock notes that it was probably owned by Parker by 1566/67, as Parkerian underlinings, scoring in the margin and pointing fingers agree closely with the citations of the Chronicle in A Defence of Priestes Mariages of that date (Whitelock 1954, p. 23). Acquired by Laud in 1636 from William L'Isle, s. xvii1 (Ker 1957, p. 426 and O'Brien O'Keeffe 2003, p. 41).
history.acquisition: Laud's gift to the Bodleian Library in 1639 (Wanley 1954, p. 426).

admin: Manuscript described by Orietta Da Rold with the assistance of Hollie Morgan and George Younge (2010; 2013).
